body: Going to the theater is, in many ways, a respectable sort of voyeurism. You pay for your ticket, grab a program and sit down in the dark to peek into the inner lives of complete strangers. It's like flipping through an Architectural Digest of other people's neuroses. ''The Sublet Experiment'' is a play that taps into the thrills of theater's
title: 'The Sublet Experiment' Puts a Different Spin on Home Theater

body: For years the label ''downtown dance'' has been used as a vague shorthand to describe certain choreographers, usually experimental ones working on a shoestring budget. But most of the downtown choreographers (who generally loathe that label) have long since fled Manhattan for affordable housing and rehearsal space in Brooklyn or one of New York
title: 'Crosstown Dance': Choreographers Balance Inspiration and a Long Commute

body: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the most popular tax break for apartment building developers, adopting a plan intended to induce them to build tens of thousands of apartments for people other than the well-heeled. The changes, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supported and which would go into effect in 2008,
title: IN OVERHAUL, CITY SEEKS TO EXPAND LOWER-COST UNITS

body: Q. Can I salvage my old chandelier? A. You should certainly try, because memorable light fixtures can serve as a signature for your house. Use color to wake up a traditional look. At the Long Island house she inherited from her grandmother Estée, Aerin Lauder has placed teal wax candles in a grand Waterford chandelier, but electrified candles can
title: ROOM TO IMPROVE

body: An off-duty police officer was stabbed in the chest early yesterday at a popular Williamsburg diner filled with an after-hours crowd, the police said. By yesterday afternoon, the police had arrested a suspect, Luis DeJesus, 21, at his home on Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and charged him with assault on a police officer. The stabbing
title: Off-Duty Officer Is Stabbed in Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: ''The House That Unhinged a Neighborhood'' (Dec. 3) mentioned that the house at 281 Starr Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, had been ''cemented shut'' and ''condemned by the city.'' What you did not mention is how this came to be accomplished in so short a period of time. Last month, I was invited to attend a town hall meeting that dealt
title: Quick Work to Close A Problem House

body: Nancy Caballero believed that her daughter, Rosa Corsino, was going to die in her hospital bed. Swollen to three times her normal size, Ms. Corsino was feverish, unable to eat and barely able to breathe. From an incision in her abdomen, a blood-red abscess had erupted and was growing like a small balloon. Yet for days, despite Ms. Caballero's
title: The Neediest Cases; Facing Bills at Home After Seeing a Daughter Through

body: In its aggressive strides to improve the quality of life, New York City has drastically curtailed its crime rate. It has overhauled its chaotic school system. But in one area, success is elusive: The city's rats remain as bold and showy as ever, darting through well-lighted subway stations as blasé New Yorkers watch and scurrying through its
title: In Epic Battle, the Rat Patrol Adjusts Its Aim and Digs In

body: Twenty-five years after New York State overhauled its property tax system under court pressure, disparities have widened in how New York City taxes real property, with many homeowners in affluent areas disproportionately benefiting from tax breaks, an analysis has found. The analysis, by the city's Independent Budget Office, found that many owners
title: Tax Breaks Seem to Favor Affluent Areas

body: Kathleen M. Cashin is responsible for some of the roughest territory in the New York City school system -- vast stretches of poverty and desolation from Ocean Hill-Brownsville and East New York in Brooklyn to Far Rockaway in Queens, all part of Region 5, where she is superintendent. Already this school year, two of her students have been shot dead,
title: Bucking Tide of School Reform, A Superintendent Gets Results

body: The house at 281 Starr Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, always seemed closed off to neighbors, at least figuratively. Described charitably as a shack, it had death-gray aluminum siding that had long ago begun peeling to reveal faux-brick siding underneath. The lone decorative feature of its four-foot-deep concrete yard was a few ailing branches stuck
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK; The House That Unhinged A Neighborhood

body: Police officers pursued and arrested two men in Brooklyn early yesterday moments after the men fatally shot a third man during an attempted robbery, and then tossed their guns onto nearby rooftops, the police said. Police say the victim, Dennis Mack, 26, died after being shot numerous times near the Bushwick Houses at Moore and Humboldt Streets in
title: In Brooklyn, a Fatal Shooting, a Police Chase and an Arrest

body: IT'S the opening night of ''The Food Show: The Hungry Eye'' at the Chelsea Art Museum, a former Christmas ornament factory that hugs the westernmost corner of 22nd Street. Rain has begun to blow off the Hudson River in heavy sheets, reversing umbrellas and lagooning the sidewalks. Inside the museum all is sleek and bland and expensive looking:
title: ART; The Debutante's Ball

body: Starrett City, a 140-acre apartment complex built 30 years ago on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn as an enclave for working-class New Yorkers, is on the auction block, the owner confirmed yesterday. The complex, whose owner changed its name in recent years to the more chic-sounding Spring Creek Towers, is the largest federally subsidized rental complex in
title: Brooklyn Tract Goes on Block; Home to 14,000

body: THE tiny foyer of Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay's co-op is decorated with oil paintings that form a trail of their former residences. The couple, who have been married for nine years, have moved a lot. There was the Brooklyn rental. The dingy Shanghai hotel room they shared with a rat. The upstate cottage they transformed from creepy to cute. And
title: HABITATS/Jackson Heights, Queens; As Permanent a Home As Any One Can Be

body: The city, starting an aggressive campaign to combat hunger and unhealthy eating, plans to name a food policy czar to help make healthier options available to poor New Yorkers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. As part of the campaign, the new official, whose title will be food policy coordinator,
title: City to Name Food Policy Official to Address Hunger Issues

body: A Bushwick man was shot to death on Jefferson Street at 1 a.m. yesterday six blocks from his apartment, the police said. Friends and relatives of the man, Raul Gutierrez, 21, said they suspected a member of the gang to which he used to belong. The police, however, said they were investigating and had no suspects. According to relatives, Mr.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot

body: It was the first of three public hearings on the $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards development, and Umar Jordan, a 51-year-old resident of Bushwick, Brooklyn, strode to the front of the auditorium and offered a vigorous defense of the proposal. ''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

author: Tyler Gray is a senior editor at Radar Magazine and Radaronline.com.
body: BEHIND a plate-glass window on West 10th Street, where the phrase ''For Men for Women'' was emblazoned in gold leaf 35 years ago, Shaun Cottle snipped away at the shock-blond locks of his client, Genesis P-Orridge. Without a word from Ms. P-Orridge, Mr. Cottle, the 34-year-old stylist and co-owner of Seagull Haircutters, knew exactly how she wanted
title: URBAN TACTICS; Where the Haircut Is Only the Beginning

body: ''Buildings are popping up like mushrooms,'' said Christopher Olechowski, 59, a member of the community board for Greenpoint and Williamsburg and a longtime resident of the area. ''Down Manhattan Avenue, all you hear are jackhammers. If you go down Kent, the road is being repaved. ''It's everywhere,'' he said. ''I have to sweep the dust off my car
title: City Sees Growth; Residents Call It Out of Control

body: THESE days, the road to Northsix is a crowded one. All along the stretch of North Sixth Street that leads to Northsix, a five-year-old rock music club by the Williamsburg waterfront, there are raucous bars, restaurants and stores. Almost none of them were there when Jeff Steinhauser, still in his 20s and armed with his inheritance money, leased
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; Polishing the Grunge

body: Ramiro Jara was lured by the same promise that drew his brothers and cousins to New York from the highlands of Ecuador six years ago. Opportunity. A new life. Wages he could never have earned back home. And he found a steady job, as a construction worker, learning how to nimbly navigate platforms and scaffolding that wrapped Manhattan's soaring
title: Construction Worker Dies in 15-Story Fall in Manhattan

body: MY friend grabbed me by the shoulders and spun me around. He paused for emphasis and then, holding me in place, declared that our lunch was personal, not business. At that point I didn't know why we were in Bushwick and I didn't know what we'd be eating. But I understood that this was his spot. His little secret. I told him we were cool. I told him
title: $25 AND UNDER; Behind a Garage Door, a Brooklyn Secret

body: An off-duty New York City police officer was killed and a colleague was injured and charged with drunken driving after the car they were riding in crashed on a Long Island highway early yesterday, the authorities said. The crash, in the westbound lanes of Sunrise Highway near the Wantagh Parkway overpass, occurred at 4:30 a.m. when a Mitsubishi
title: Officer Charged as Drunken Driver in Crash That Killed Colleague

body: To the Editor: ''Shutting Out Minorities'' (editorial, Sept. 3) was a welcome call for rebuilding failed public middle schools in underserved areas. Yet your prescription to remedy the problem reinforces, rather than dismantles, a barrier to meaningful school reform. The issue at hand will not be solved by more surveys and statistical analyses, as
title: The 'Achievement Gap' And Minority Students

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: It's hard to think of many contemporary New York artists who, personally and professionally, have experienced the highs and lows of John Moran, whose latest work, ''Zenith 5,'' was presented last night at Spiegeltent at the former Fulton Fish Market, under the Brooklyn Bridge. Mr. Moran is best known as a composer and director of unconventional
title: From Opera to Dance: His New Style, No Sweat

body: Leaders of a mayoral commission charged with working to eradicate poverty in New York City are scaling back wider ambitions to instead focus on helping three distinct populations: young children, young adults and the working poor. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg formed the panel in January to draw up a template for his administration to attack chronic
title: Mayor's Panel Set to Recommend Scaled-Back Approach to Fighting Poverty

body: A man died in police custody yesterday after complaining about a heart problem and swollen legs, the police said. The man, Ronald Clemons, 45, of Bushwick, had been arrested and charged with driving with a suspended license and criminal possession of a controlled substance shortly after 7 p.m. He was taken to a hospital, but was returned to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In Police Custody

body: LIKE many, I came to New York City with the dream of becoming an artist. And so, in the early 1990's, I moved into an illegal loft space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, hoping the grime and inconvenience of this bohemian nest would foster my creativity; no matter that I didn't have much talent or experience. That was then, this is now. I have a day job,
title: Life Lessons: Beginner's Guide to Walk-In Art Classes

body: With the Bloomberg administration pushing forward in its drive to create more than 200 small schools, city education officials have crashed into a cold reality that has long vexed New York City dwellers: They are running out of space. In the Bronx, 500 students in two high schools are not sure where they will go when classes start next month. The
title: In Push to Open Small Schools, A Big Obstacle: Limited Space

body: IT was a sweltering Saturday afternoon on an L train hurtling across Manhattan toward Brooklyn. The last car held the usual assortment of characters: two women shrieking about a recent outing to a hardware store while a man lounged before them, guffawing; a young woman hiding behind sunglasses and iPod earbuds; a scruffy man slumped beside his
title: ART; Watch the Closing Doors, And Mind the Zombies

body: A man on a bicycle fatally shot another man who was standing at an intersection in Bushwick yesterday, the police said. One witness said he was standing about 30 feet away from the victim, at the corner of Troutman Street and Evergreen Avenue, when the bicyclist drove up and without a word began firing at close range. The victim, who was not
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bicyclist Kills Man, Police Say

body: YOU may never have had a really terrific taco, especially if you live on the East Coast. There are a lot of tacos around, certainly, and many of them can be satisfying enough. But the genuine article is often hard to come by -- except in Mexico, on the West Coast and in the Southwest, where taco passion runs deep. And when the Westerners travel
title: The Taco Joint in Your Kitchen

body: The highest temperature officially recorded on Earth was 136.4 degrees, registered on Sept. 13, 1922, in Al Àziziyah, Libya. Adel Alakhder, 40, who is from Libya, moved to New York in 2005. He said he remembered how, as a boy, he enjoyed the hot, dusty ghibli winds that descended from the country's inland mountains toward the Mediterranean Sea.
title: Think of It This Way: It Could Be 136

body: It is often the most emotionally charged period during a criminal trial: the brief interlude between the time the jurors notify the court that they have reached a verdict, and the moment when they deliver it. But yesterday, in United States District Court in Brooklyn, Baldassare Amato, a longtime Bonanno soldier who is facing life in prison on
title: Guilty Verdict For 3 in Case Involving Bonanno Clan

body: COACHED toward the curb by her own impromptu valet parking attendant -- in his actual job the well-mannered executive director of Working Playground, an arts-education nonprofit group that serves New York City schoolchildren -- the actress Rosie Perez halts her sporty black Volvo station wagon and hands him the keys. Girl's got clout. Not that she
title: PUBLIC LIVES; 'Do the Right Thing' Is More Than Her Movie Debut

body: TO escape the frenetic pace of city life, Troy and L. Camille Thornton need only slip out through the glass door of their bedroom in SoHo. There, tucked away on an expansive deck, sits a verdant garden of rose of Sharon, lavender and andromeda, along with Hinoki cypress, Japanese maple and cherry trees, artfully displayed in jardinieres and wooden
title: Rethinking the Balcony

body: Nearly three years after it revamped its rat control program, the city health department still takes too long to investigate complaints about rodents, according to an audit released yesterday. The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said it was trying to improve its performance, but noted that its workload had surged during the period covered
title: Rats Are Swift, but Audit Finds Response to Them Is Sluggish

body: LAST Sunday, Mount Sinai Baptist Church on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was full of large, tough-looking men in tears. They were among a crowd of about 300 mourners at the funeral of George Washington, a man who had changed many of their lives. Until shortly before he died on June 11 at 79, Mr. Washington was the driving force
title: Their Requiem for a Heavyweight

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AFTER months of uncertainty about the fate of 184 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn -- would it be designated a landmark or would its conversion to condominiums proceed directly? -- the renters there were finally evicted. ''Every day, there were moving vans,'' said Eric Johnston, one of the tenants. ''It was like pouring gas on an anthill.'' He
title: THE HUNT; A Compromise, With Three Days to Spare

body: A New York City panel is examining whether the city should subsidize job centers for day laborers to link this overwhelmingly immigrant work force to prospective employers and curb wage and workplace abuses. The job centers would bring a measure of regulation to an informal economy that involves throngs of immigrants gathering on curbsides and in
title: City to Consider Job Centers For Day Labor

body: WAY beyond Williamsburg's so-called hippest L train stops, past the fringes of what is supposed (by brokers, at least) to be ''East Williamsburg,'' things are happening in Bushwick. Waking up from the haze of a questionable reputation and offering relatively low-cost residential options, this large neighborhood has buyers and developers taking new
title: LIVING IN/Bushwick, Brooklyn; Bargain-Hunting? Stay on the L Train a Little Longer

body: A man prosecutors say is a longtime mob soldier who was present at one of New York's most storied Mafia assassinations went on trial yesterday in Federal District Court on racketeering conspiracy charges that include two other murders. The defendant, Baldassare Amato, 54, is charged with the 1992 killings of Robert Perrino, a Bonanno family
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mob Trial Begins

body: A fast-moving fire broke out in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, killing a disabled woman and leaving her 1-year-old granddaughter in critical condition, their relatives and the police said. Both were victims of smoke inhalation, the police said. The fire started about 5:15 p.m. in a back bedroom of the 10th-floor, four-bedroom apartment in the
title: Woman Dies and Infant Granddaughter Is Critically Hurt in Fire

body: Nine former employees of a Brooklyn supermarket have filed a suit accusing the store and its owners of forcing them to work long hours with no breaks, paid only in customer tips. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court on Tuesday afternoon, seeks $1.56 million in back pay and overtime from the supermarket's parent company, Bogopa Service
title: 9 Former Workers Sue a Brooklyn Supermarket for Back Pay

body: TURBO TERRIFIC -- a D.J. who gave no other name -- was standing on an overturned milk crate in front of a tall bookshelf filled with records. ''I don't think of myself as a record collector,'' he said as he flipped through the records on the top shelf. ''Collecting is like a cult; it's crazy. Records are dusty, they take up space, and they weigh a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Vinyl Underground

body: There have been at least four deliberately set fires at properties linked to Joshua Guttman, the owner of a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront that burned to the ground this week in what Fire Department officials have called suspicious circumstances, according to records collected by fire marshals. Details of the other fires, which date
title: Arson Was Found at 4 of Warehouse Owner's Properties

body: LUZ STELLA BONGIOVI has a job that many people would envy. After 12 years in the same business, she supervises more than 100 employees and logs about 50 hours a week, coming into work at 10 a.m. and often working at home. She has been sent on junkets to Hawaii, Las Vegas and Puerto Rico. Her earnings total nearly $170,000 a year. Her job title:
title: For the Avon Lady, a World Beyond Ringing Doorbells

body: For 13 years, two families lived with a secret in the concrete in Brooklyn. Virginia Randall raised 10 boys and girls in a house in Bushwick, her own sons and the children of her sisters. With five bedrooms on a lower floor, two in the middle and a rented apartment on top, the house was a busy one, the good times of graduation parties contrasting
title: Mystery of Man Gone 13 Years Ends in Brooklyn Court

body: Jonah Bokaer wasn't trying to be cute when he named his arts center Chez Bushwick. ''I was thinking about the Salon des Refusés, which exhibited alternative, often controversial work in 19th-century France,'' he said. ''Chez Bushwick is a house or a maison. It's a safe zone for artists where anything can happen.'' There is a socialist flavor to
title: DANCE; Grab a Beer and Watch Dance Grow in Brooklyn

body: SOME neighborhoods in the city are unofficially designated as among the prettiest. Others are deemed to be the hippest. If there were a contest for the tidiest, Ridgewood, Queens, would be up there among the finalists. In this small working-class enclave abutting Bushwick, Brooklyn, barely 20 minutes from Manhattan by subway, street after street is
title: LIVING IN/Ridgewood, Queens; A Neat Enclave Enriched by Waves of Immigrants

body: THE deadline for filing income taxes was inching closer, and the waiting area of the Financial Clinic was filled with people carrying not just shoeboxes full of carefully assembled financial documents but also manila folders, leather purses, even shopping bags. Nonetheless, the choppy waters of Schedule C's, 1099's and earned-income tax credits
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES -- Filing; Before the Taxman Knocketh

body: Joseph J. Esposito enjoys, among the rank and file of the New York Police Department, a reputation as a ''cop's cop,'' as much a product of the department as any school or neighborhood, joining at age 18 in the bygone days of officer trainees. In the almost 38 years since he became a trainee, he has risen to be the highest-ranking member of the
title: Colleagues of Police Chief Cite His Bond With Jews

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: BRIGHTEN school walls and brighten students' prospects. It's all part of the same palette, according to a group that runs a program in which students in New York City's middle and high schools volunteer to paint the halls, cafeterias and other common areas of older schools in vibrant tones of yellow, green, blue, red and orange. The nonprofit
title: HOME FRONT; A Paint Job? Yes, and a Painting Job, Too

body: AT midnight one recent Friday, dozens of people lined up in one of Brooklyn's bleakest warehouse districts, waiting to enter a rock show. Tickets had been sold at a Greenpoint record store, but the show's address was only revealed to buyers at the last minute by e-mail. A ticket taker stamped the hands of nearly 500 fans who eventually jammed into
title: Dark 2BR Loft? That's Code for a Club

author: E-mail: streetlevel@nytimes.com
body: A STEADY line of cars, mainly yellow taxis and white limousines, crawled eastward through the night past the floodlit entrances to two of Manhattan's best-known nightspots, the strip club Scores and the nightclub Crobar. Each time a car stopped for more than a few seconds, a driver impatiently honked his horn. It was 2:30 a.m. on a Saturday in West
title: STREET LEVEL/West Chelsea; In Club Land, 'Neighbors' Doesn't Mean Nearby

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. ''Cosmic Collisions,'' a sky show devoted to cosmic events past and future, is shown daily every 30 minutes, from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (until 7 p.m. on the first Friday of every month), except at noon and 3 p.m.,
title: Spare Times

body: A 2-year old girl was beaten by her mother and critically injured, the authorities said. The mother, Antonia Ramirez, 30, was arraigned early today on charges of assault and reckless endangerment and was held without bail. Prosecutors said that in a videotaped statement, Ms. Ramirez admitted shoving her daughter into an entertainment center in her
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Charged In Child's Beating

body: Donna Fenton no longer consults the scrap of paper in her pocketbook when she needs the phone number for the Red Cross, or New York City's welfare office, or the Federal Emergency Management Agency. ''I know them all by heart,'' said Ms. Fenton, 37, who left Biloxi, Miss., after Hurricane Katrina destroyed her home there. ''I call them every day.
title: For Katrina Evacuee, Getting Help Is a Full-Time Job

author: Robert Sullivan is the author of ''Rats: Observations on the History and Habitat of the City's Most Unwanted Inhabitants'' and ''How Not to Get Rich: Why Being Bad Off Isn't So Bad.''
body: On a rainy winter afternoon, just a few minutes after running over a stray hubcap, just after having to pull his beat-up Toyota sedan off a beat-up section of the beat-up Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and having to run the little white car back and forth until at last the hubcap broke free, Tom Le, choreographer-turned-real-estate-agent, re-enters the
title: The Next Neighborhood; Psst Have You Heard About Bushwick?

author: E-mail: dabarry@nytimes.com
body: THE best and nicest pool player in New York City shoots the break. The white cue ball rockets into a triangle of 15 numbered balls, clattering and scattering stripes and solids to the ends of their green felt domain. Three balls hurl themselves into pockets, as if to hide. Tony Robles, already chalking up for his next shot, studies the crazed
title: About New York; Filling All the Pockets, Except His Own

body: Jason Griffiths stopped short of announcing that scientia est potentia -- knowledge is power -- when he spoke to a small audience the other night in the auditorium of Public School 147 in Bushwick, Brooklyn. He did, however, paint a vivid picture of what will be known as the Brooklyn Latin School, a new high school that will open in the fall on the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK; A New School In Brooklyn: A Bit of Boston, A Lot of Rome

body: It is, in a heartbreaking way, a variant on the classic immigrant story. Kassoum Fofana grew up in Bobo-Dioulasso, the second-largest city in the landlocked West African country of Burkina Faso. Mr. Fofana, a quick-witted and ambitious young man, was good with his hands and became a carpenter. He met a woman. Her name was Assita Coulibaly. A funny,
title: Fire Puts a Sad Ending on an Optimistic Immigrant Tale

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Mush! Mush! Q. I occasionally pass a crumbling mansion in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that was owned by Frederick Cook, who claimed to have discovered the North Pole. Is this a Santa Claus story? A. In a way, yes. The vacant Victorian house at Bushwick and Willoughby Avenues was once the home of Dr. Frederick A. Cook (1865-1940), a physician, polar
title: F. Y. I.

body: The tips have slowed to a trickle, and the leads have all but dried up. Detectives know little more about what happened to Rashawn Brazell, whose limbs and torso they found in trash bags in a subway tunnel and in a recycling plant in Brooklyn last year, than they did in the weeks after he vanished from his home in Bushwick. In some ways they know
title: A Year After a Teenager Was Dismembered, Still No Answer

body: Four years after President Bush signed the landmark No Child Left Behind education law, vast numbers of students are not getting the tutoring that the law offers as one of its hallmarks. In the nation's largest school district, New York City, fewer than half of the 215,000 eligible students sought the free tutoring, according to figures from the
title: TUTOR PROGRAM OFFERED BY LAW IS GOING UNUSED

body: Among the thousands of stores in New York's low-income neighborhoods, labor unions have virtually no presence, except in a few supermarkets. But in a remarkable culmination to a yearlong struggle, 95 workers at a chain of 10 sneaker stores have formed a union. For much of last year, workers with the sneaker chain, Footco, protested what they said
title: In Modern Rarity, Workers Form Union at Small Chain

body: One man was fatally stabbed and another injured late on Friday during a knife fight among card players in the back of a Brooklyn barbershop, the police and area residents said. One of the men, Osiris Sanchez, 25, who was stabbed in the chest at the Garcia Barbershop at 1245 Halsey Street in Bushwick about 10 p.m., was taken to Wyckoff Heights
title: 2 Men Are Stabbed, One Fatally, In Fight in Brooklyn Barbershop

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used the first State of the City speech of his new term yesterday to call for a drastic change in the World Trade Center development plan so the project can finally move forward. He also asked unions to accept changes to health insurance and pension benefits, whose costs, he said, ''have spiraled out of control.'' In an
title: MAYOR, IN SPEECH, URGES SWIFT PACE AT GROUND ZERO

body: As the pay and purchasing power of Manhattan residents have moved higher and higher, incomes in all four of the boroughs outside Manhattan have trailed inflation over the last few years, in a stark example of the increasing income disparity in New York City. In terms of wages, Manhattan families are doing better on average than those in the rest of
title: Wage Squeeze Hits All of City But Manhattan

body: Look in just about any bodega in the city's poorer neighborhoods and it is easy to find shelves well-stocked with potato chips, sodas and doughnuts. But just try to find something healthier like fruits or vegetables. For many low-income city residents, such bodegas are more common shopping options than supermarkets with a much larger roster of
title: Bodegas Are Asked by Health Officials to Help Push a Better Diet in Poorer Neighborhoods

body: When Christine C. Quinn secured enough support last week to become the next City Council speaker, a subtle shift in the political landscape of the city became evident: The Brooklyn Democratic Party was back, playing a role, albeit a minor one, in her victory. The party provided support that helped clinch Ms. Quinn's victory, potentially giving the
title: Brooklyn Democrats Regain Some Clout After Scandals

body: Going to the theater is, in many ways, a respectable sort of voyeurism. You pay for your ticket, grab a program and sit down in the dark to peek into the inner lives of complete strangers. It's like flipping through an Architectural Digest of other people's neuroses. ''The Sublet Experiment'' is a play that taps into the thrills of theater's
title: 'The Sublet Experiment' Puts a Different Spin on Home Theater

body: For years the label ''downtown dance'' has been used as a vague shorthand to describe certain choreographers, usually experimental ones working on a shoestring budget. But most of the downtown choreographers (who generally loathe that label) have long since fled Manhattan for affordable housing and rehearsal space in Brooklyn or one of New York
title: 'Crosstown Dance': Choreographers Balance Inspiration and a Long Commute

body: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the most popular tax break for apartment building developers, adopting a plan intended to induce them to build tens of thousands of apartments for people other than the well-heeled. The changes, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supported and which would go into effect in 2008,
title: IN OVERHAUL, CITY SEEKS TO EXPAND LOWER-COST UNITS

body: Q. Can I salvage my old chandelier? A. You should certainly try, because memorable light fixtures can serve as a signature for your house. Use color to wake up a traditional look. At the Long Island house she inherited from her grandmother Estée, Aerin Lauder has placed teal wax candles in a grand Waterford chandelier, but electrified candles can
title: ROOM TO IMPROVE

body: An off-duty police officer was stabbed in the chest early yesterday at a popular Williamsburg diner filled with an after-hours crowd, the police said. By yesterday afternoon, the police had arrested a suspect, Luis DeJesus, 21, at his home on Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and charged him with assault on a police officer. The stabbing
title: Off-Duty Officer Is Stabbed in Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: ''The House That Unhinged a Neighborhood'' (Dec. 3) mentioned that the house at 281 Starr Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, had been ''cemented shut'' and ''condemned by the city.'' What you did not mention is how this came to be accomplished in so short a period of time. Last month, I was invited to attend a town hall meeting that dealt
title: Quick Work to Close A Problem House

body: Nancy Caballero believed that her daughter, Rosa Corsino, was going to die in her hospital bed. Swollen to three times her normal size, Ms. Corsino was feverish, unable to eat and barely able to breathe. From an incision in her abdomen, a blood-red abscess had erupted and was growing like a small balloon. Yet for days, despite Ms. Caballero's
title: The Neediest Cases; Facing Bills at Home After Seeing a Daughter Through

body: In its aggressive strides to improve the quality of life, New York City has drastically curtailed its crime rate. It has overhauled its chaotic school system. But in one area, success is elusive: The city's rats remain as bold and showy as ever, darting through well-lighted subway stations as blasé New Yorkers watch and scurrying through its
title: In Epic Battle, the Rat Patrol Adjusts Its Aim and Digs In

body: Twenty-five years after New York State overhauled its property tax system under court pressure, disparities have widened in how New York City taxes real property, with many homeowners in affluent areas disproportionately benefiting from tax breaks, an analysis has found. The analysis, by the city's Independent Budget Office, found that many owners
title: Tax Breaks Seem to Favor Affluent Areas

body: Kathleen M. Cashin is responsible for some of the roughest territory in the New York City school system -- vast stretches of poverty and desolation from Ocean Hill-Brownsville and East New York in Brooklyn to Far Rockaway in Queens, all part of Region 5, where she is superintendent. Already this school year, two of her students have been shot dead,
title: Bucking Tide of School Reform, A Superintendent Gets Results

body: The house at 281 Starr Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, always seemed closed off to neighbors, at least figuratively. Described charitably as a shack, it had death-gray aluminum siding that had long ago begun peeling to reveal faux-brick siding underneath. The lone decorative feature of its four-foot-deep concrete yard was a few ailing branches stuck
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK; The House That Unhinged A Neighborhood

body: Police officers pursued and arrested two men in Brooklyn early yesterday moments after the men fatally shot a third man during an attempted robbery, and then tossed their guns onto nearby rooftops, the police said. Police say the victim, Dennis Mack, 26, died after being shot numerous times near the Bushwick Houses at Moore and Humboldt Streets in
title: In Brooklyn, a Fatal Shooting, a Police Chase and an Arrest

body: IT'S the opening night of ''The Food Show: The Hungry Eye'' at the Chelsea Art Museum, a former Christmas ornament factory that hugs the westernmost corner of 22nd Street. Rain has begun to blow off the Hudson River in heavy sheets, reversing umbrellas and lagooning the sidewalks. Inside the museum all is sleek and bland and expensive looking:
title: ART; The Debutante's Ball

body: Starrett City, a 140-acre apartment complex built 30 years ago on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn as an enclave for working-class New Yorkers, is on the auction block, the owner confirmed yesterday. The complex, whose owner changed its name in recent years to the more chic-sounding Spring Creek Towers, is the largest federally subsidized rental complex in
title: Brooklyn Tract Goes on Block; Home to 14,000

body: THE tiny foyer of Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay's co-op is decorated with oil paintings that form a trail of their former residences. The couple, who have been married for nine years, have moved a lot. There was the Brooklyn rental. The dingy Shanghai hotel room they shared with a rat. The upstate cottage they transformed from creepy to cute. And
title: HABITATS/Jackson Heights, Queens; As Permanent a Home As Any One Can Be

body: The city, starting an aggressive campaign to combat hunger and unhealthy eating, plans to name a food policy czar to help make healthier options available to poor New Yorkers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. As part of the campaign, the new official, whose title will be food policy coordinator,
title: City to Name Food Policy Official to Address Hunger Issues

Friends and relatives of the man, Raul Gutierrez, 21, said they suspected a member of the gang to which he used to belong. The police, however, said they were investigating and had no suspects. According to relatives, Mr.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot

''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

body: BEHIND a plate-glass window on West 10th Street, where the phrase ''For Men for Women'' was emblazoned in gold leaf 35 years ago, Shaun Cottle snipped away at the shock-blond locks of his client, Genesis P-Orridge. Without a word from Ms. P-Orridge, Mr. Cottle, the 34-year-old stylist and co-owner of Seagull Haircutters, knew exactly how she wanted
title: URBAN TACTICS; Where the Haircut Is Only the Beginning

body: ''Buildings are popping up like mushrooms,'' said Christopher Olechowski, 59, a member of the community board for Greenpoint and Williamsburg and a longtime resident of the area. ''Down Manhattan Avenue, all you hear are jackhammers. If you go down Kent, the road is being repaved. ''It's everywhere,'' he said. ''I have to sweep the dust off my car
title: City Sees Growth; Residents Call It Out of Control

body: THESE days, the road to Northsix is a crowded one. All along the stretch of North Sixth Street that leads to Northsix, a five-year-old rock music club by the Williamsburg waterfront, there are raucous bars, restaurants and stores. Almost none of them were there when Jeff Steinhauser, still in his 20s and armed with his inheritance money, leased
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; Polishing the Grunge

body: Ramiro Jara was lured by the same promise that drew his brothers and cousins to New York from the highlands of Ecuador six years ago. Opportunity. A new life. Wages he could never have earned back home. And he found a steady job, as a construction worker, learning how to nimbly navigate platforms and scaffolding that wrapped Manhattan's soaring
title: Construction Worker Dies in 15-Story Fall in Manhattan

body: MY friend grabbed me by the shoulders and spun me around. He paused for emphasis and then, holding me in place, declared that our lunch was personal, not business. At that point I didn't know why we were in Bushwick and I didn't know what we'd be eating. But I understood that this was his spot. His little secret. I told him we were cool. I told him
title: $25 AND UNDER; Behind a Garage Door, a Brooklyn Secret

The crash, in the westbound lanes of Sunrise Highway near the Wantagh Parkway overpass, occurred at 4:30 a.m. when a Mitsubishi
title: Officer Charged as Drunken Driver in Crash That Killed Colleague

body: To the Editor: ''Shutting Out Minorities'' (editorial, Sept. 3) was a welcome call for rebuilding failed public middle schools in underserved areas. Yet your prescription to remedy the problem reinforces, rather than dismantles, a barrier to meaningful school reform. The issue at hand will not be solved by more surveys and statistical analyses, as
title: The 'Achievement Gap' And Minority Students

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: It's hard to think of many contemporary New York artists who, personally and professionally, have experienced the highs and lows of John Moran, whose latest work, ''Zenith 5,'' was presented last night at Spiegeltent at the former Fulton Fish Market, under the Brooklyn Bridge. Mr. Moran is best known as a composer and director of unconventional
title: From Opera to Dance: His New Style, No Sweat

body: Leaders of a mayoral commission charged with working to eradicate poverty in New York City are scaling back wider ambitions to instead focus on helping three distinct populations: young children, young adults and the working poor. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg formed the panel in January to draw up a template for his administration to attack chronic
title: Mayor's Panel Set to Recommend Scaled-Back Approach to Fighting Poverty

body: A man died in police custody yesterday after complaining about a heart problem and swollen legs, the police said. The man, Ronald Clemons, 45, of Bushwick, had been arrested and charged with driving with a suspended license and criminal possession of a controlled substance shortly after 7 p.m. He was taken to a hospital, but was returned to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In Police Custody

body: LIKE many, I came to New York City with the dream of becoming an artist. And so, in the early 1990's, I moved into an illegal loft space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, hoping the grime and inconvenience of this bohemian nest would foster my creativity; no matter that I didn't have much talent or experience. That was then, this is now. I have a day job,
title: Life Lessons: Beginner's Guide to Walk-In Art Classes

body: With the Bloomberg administration pushing forward in its drive to create more than 200 small schools, city education officials have crashed into a cold reality that has long vexed New York City dwellers: They are running out of space. In the Bronx, 500 students in two high schools are not sure where they will go when classes start next month. The
title: In Push to Open Small Schools, A Big Obstacle: Limited Space

body: IT was a sweltering Saturday afternoon on an L train hurtling across Manhattan toward Brooklyn. The last car held the usual assortment of characters: two women shrieking about a recent outing to a hardware store while a man lounged before them, guffawing; a young woman hiding behind sunglasses and iPod earbuds; a scruffy man slumped beside his
title: ART; Watch the Closing Doors, And Mind the Zombies

body: A man on a bicycle fatally shot another man who was standing at an intersection in Bushwick yesterday, the police said. One witness said he was standing about 30 feet away from the victim, at the corner of Troutman Street and Evergreen Avenue, when the bicyclist drove up and without a word began firing at close range. The victim, who was not
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bicyclist Kills Man, Police Say

body: YOU may never have had a really terrific taco, especially if you live on the East Coast. There are a lot of tacos around, certainly, and many of them can be satisfying enough. But the genuine article is often hard to come by -- except in Mexico, on the West Coast and in the Southwest, where taco passion runs deep. And when the Westerners travel
title: The Taco Joint in Your Kitchen

body: The highest temperature officially recorded on Earth was 136.4 degrees, registered on Sept. 13, 1922, in Al Àziziyah, Libya. Adel Alakhder, 40, who is from Libya, moved to New York in 2005. He said he remembered how, as a boy, he enjoyed the hot, dusty ghibli winds that descended from the country's inland mountains toward the Mediterranean Sea.
title: Think of It This Way: It Could Be 136

body: It is often the most emotionally charged period during a criminal trial: the brief interlude between the time the jurors notify the court that they have reached a verdict, and the moment when they deliver it. But yesterday, in United States District Court in Brooklyn, Baldassare Amato, a longtime Bonanno soldier who is facing life in prison on
title: Guilty Verdict For 3 in Case Involving Bonanno Clan

Girl's got clout. Not that she
title: PUBLIC LIVES; 'Do the Right Thing' Is More Than Her Movie Debut

body: TO escape the frenetic pace of city life, Troy and L. Camille Thornton need only slip out through the glass door of their bedroom in SoHo. There, tucked away on an expansive deck, sits a verdant garden of rose of Sharon, lavender and andromeda, along with Hinoki cypress, Japanese maple and cherry trees, artfully displayed in jardinieres and wooden
title: Rethinking the Balcony

body: Nearly three years after it revamped its rat control program, the city health department still takes too long to investigate complaints about rodents, according to an audit released yesterday. The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said it was trying to improve its performance, but noted that its workload had surged during the period covered
title: Rats Are Swift, but Audit Finds Response to Them Is Sluggish

body: LAST Sunday, Mount Sinai Baptist Church on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was full of large, tough-looking men in tears. They were among a crowd of about 300 mourners at the funeral of George Washington, a man who had changed many of their lives. Until shortly before he died on June 11 at 79, Mr. Washington was the driving force
title: Their Requiem for a Heavyweight

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AFTER months of uncertainty about the fate of 184 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn -- would it be designated a landmark or would its conversion to condominiums proceed directly? -- the renters there were finally evicted. ''Every day, there were moving vans,'' said Eric Johnston, one of the tenants. ''It was like pouring gas on an anthill.'' He
title: THE HUNT; A Compromise, With Three Days to Spare

body: A New York City panel is examining whether the city should subsidize job centers for day laborers to link this overwhelmingly immigrant work force to prospective employers and curb wage and workplace abuses. The job centers would bring a measure of regulation to an informal economy that involves throngs of immigrants gathering on curbsides and in
title: City to Consider Job Centers For Day Labor

body: WAY beyond Williamsburg's so-called hippest L train stops, past the fringes of what is supposed (by brokers, at least) to be ''East Williamsburg,'' things are happening in Bushwick. Waking up from the haze of a questionable reputation and offering relatively low-cost residential options, this large neighborhood has buyers and developers taking new
title: LIVING IN/Bushwick, Brooklyn; Bargain-Hunting? Stay on the L Train a Little Longer

body: A man prosecutors say is a longtime mob soldier who was present at one of New York's most storied Mafia assassinations went on trial yesterday in Federal District Court on racketeering conspiracy charges that include two other murders. The defendant, Baldassare Amato, 54, is charged with the 1992 killings of Robert Perrino, a Bonanno family
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mob Trial Begins

body: A fast-moving fire broke out in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, killing a disabled woman and leaving her 1-year-old granddaughter in critical condition, their relatives and the police said. Both were victims of smoke inhalation, the police said. The fire started about 5:15 p.m. in a back bedroom of the 10th-floor, four-bedroom apartment in the
title: Woman Dies and Infant Granddaughter Is Critically Hurt in Fire

body: Nine former employees of a Brooklyn supermarket have filed a suit accusing the store and its owners of forcing them to work long hours with no breaks, paid only in customer tips. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court on Tuesday afternoon, seeks $1.56 million in back pay and overtime from the supermarket's parent company, Bogopa Service
title: 9 Former Workers Sue a Brooklyn Supermarket for Back Pay

body: TURBO TERRIFIC -- a D.J. who gave no other name -- was standing on an overturned milk crate in front of a tall bookshelf filled with records. ''I don't think of myself as a record collector,'' he said as he flipped through the records on the top shelf. ''Collecting is like a cult; it's crazy. Records are dusty, they take up space, and they weigh a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Vinyl Underground

body: There have been at least four deliberately set fires at properties linked to Joshua Guttman, the owner of a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront that burned to the ground this week in what Fire Department officials have called suspicious circumstances, according to records collected by fire marshals. Details of the other fires, which date
title: Arson Was Found at 4 of Warehouse Owner's Properties

body: LUZ STELLA BONGIOVI has a job that many people would envy. After 12 years in the same business, she supervises more than 100 employees and logs about 50 hours a week, coming into work at 10 a.m. and often working at home. She has been sent on junkets to Hawaii, Las Vegas and Puerto Rico. Her earnings total nearly $170,000 a year. Her job title:
title: For the Avon Lady, a World Beyond Ringing Doorbells

body: For 13 years, two families lived with a secret in the concrete in Brooklyn. Virginia Randall raised 10 boys and girls in a house in Bushwick, her own sons and the children of her sisters. With five bedrooms on a lower floor, two in the middle and a rented apartment on top, the house was a busy one, the good times of graduation parties contrasting
title: Mystery of Man Gone 13 Years Ends in Brooklyn Court

body: Jonah Bokaer wasn't trying to be cute when he named his arts center Chez Bushwick. ''I was thinking about the Salon des Refusés, which exhibited alternative, often controversial work in 19th-century France,'' he said. ''Chez Bushwick is a house or a maison. It's a safe zone for artists where anything can happen.'' There is a socialist flavor to
title: DANCE; Grab a Beer and Watch Dance Grow in Brooklyn

body: SOME neighborhoods in the city are unofficially designated as among the prettiest. Others are deemed to be the hippest. If there were a contest for the tidiest, Ridgewood, Queens, would be up there among the finalists. In this small working-class enclave abutting Bushwick, Brooklyn, barely 20 minutes from Manhattan by subway, street after street is
title: LIVING IN/Ridgewood, Queens; A Neat Enclave Enriched by Waves of Immigrants

Nonetheless, the choppy waters of Schedule C's, 1099's and earned-income tax credits
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES -- Filing; Before the Taxman Knocketh

Esposito enjoys, among the rank and file of the New York Police Department, a reputation as a ''cop's cop,'' as much a product of the department as any school or neighborhood, joining at age 18 in the bygone days of officer trainees. In the almost 38 years since he became a trainee, he has risen to be the highest-ranking member of the
title: Colleagues of Police Chief Cite His Bond With Jews

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: BRIGHTEN school walls and brighten students' prospects. It's all part of the same palette, according to a group that runs a program in which students in New York City's middle and high schools volunteer to paint the halls, cafeterias and other common areas of older schools in vibrant tones of yellow, green, blue, red and orange. The nonprofit
title: HOME FRONT; A Paint Job? Yes, and a Painting Job, Too

body: AT midnight one recent Friday, dozens of people lined up in one of Brooklyn's bleakest warehouse districts, waiting to enter a rock show. Tickets had been sold at a Greenpoint record store, but the show's address was only revealed to buyers at the last minute by e-mail. A ticket taker stamped the hands of nearly 500 fans who eventually jammed into
title: Dark 2BR Loft? That's Code for a Club

body: A STEADY line of cars, mainly yellow taxis and white limousines, crawled eastward through the night past the floodlit entrances to two of Manhattan's best-known nightspots, the strip club Scores and the nightclub Crobar. Each time a car stopped for more than a few seconds, a driver impatiently honked his horn. It was 2:30 a.m. on a Saturday in West
title: STREET LEVEL/West Chelsea; In Club Land, 'Neighbors' Doesn't Mean Nearby

''Cosmic Collisions,'' a sky show devoted to cosmic events past and future, is shown daily every 30 minutes, from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (until 7 p.m. on the first Friday of every month), except at noon and 3 p.m.,
title: Spare Times

body: A 2-year old girl was beaten by her mother and critically injured, the authorities said. The mother, Antonia Ramirez, 30, was arraigned early today on charges of assault and reckless endangerment and was held without bail. Prosecutors said that in a videotaped statement, Ms. Ramirez admitted shoving her daughter into an entertainment center in her
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Charged In Child's Beating

body: Donna Fenton no longer consults the scrap of paper in her pocketbook when she needs the phone number for the Red Cross, or New York City's welfare office, or the Federal Emergency Management Agency. ''I know them all by heart,'' said Ms. Fenton, 37, who left Biloxi, Miss., after Hurricane Katrina destroyed her home there. ''I call them every day.
title: For Katrina Evacuee, Getting Help Is a Full-Time Job

author: Robert Sullivan is the author of ''Rats: Observations on the History and Habitat of the City's Most Unwanted Inhabitants'' and ''How Not to Get Rich: Why Being Bad Off Isn't So Bad.''
body: On a rainy winter afternoon, just a few minutes after running over a stray hubcap, just after having to pull his beat-up Toyota sedan off a beat-up section of the beat-up Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and having to run the little white car back and forth until at last the hubcap broke free, Tom Le, choreographer-turned-real-estate-agent, re-enters the
title: The Next Neighborhood; Psst Have You Heard About Bushwick?

body: THE best and nicest pool player in New York City shoots the break. The white cue ball rockets into a triangle of 15 numbered balls, clattering and scattering stripes and solids to the ends of their green felt domain. Three balls hurl themselves into pockets, as if to hide. Tony Robles, already chalking up for his next shot, studies the crazed
title: About New York; Filling All the Pockets, Except His Own

body: Jason Griffiths stopped short of announcing that scientia est potentia -- knowledge is power -- when he spoke to a small audience the other night in the auditorium of Public School 147 in Bushwick, Brooklyn. He did, however, paint a vivid picture of what will be known as the Brooklyn Latin School, a new high school that will open in the fall on the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK; A New School In Brooklyn: A Bit of Boston, A Lot of Rome

body: It is, in a heartbreaking way, a variant on the classic immigrant story. Kassoum Fofana grew up in Bobo-Dioulasso, the second-largest city in the landlocked West African country of Burkina Faso. Mr. Fofana, a quick-witted and ambitious young man, was good with his hands and became a carpenter. He met a woman. Her name was Assita Coulibaly. A funny,
title: Fire Puts a Sad Ending on an Optimistic Immigrant Tale

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Mush! Mush! Q. I occasionally pass a crumbling mansion in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that was owned by Frederick Cook, who claimed to have discovered the North Pole. Is this a Santa Claus story? A. In a way, yes. The vacant Victorian house at Bushwick and Willoughby Avenues was once the home of Dr. Frederick A. Cook (1865-1940), a physician, polar
title: F. Y. I.

body: The tips have slowed to a trickle, and the leads have all but dried up. Detectives know little more about what happened to Rashawn Brazell, whose limbs and torso they found in trash bags in a subway tunnel and in a recycling plant in Brooklyn last year, than they did in the weeks after he vanished from his home in Bushwick. In some ways they know
title: A Year After a Teenager Was Dismembered, Still No Answer

body: Four years after President Bush signed the landmark No Child Left Behind education law, vast numbers of students are not getting the tutoring that the law offers as one of its hallmarks. In the nation's largest school district, New York City, fewer than half of the 215,000 eligible students sought the free tutoring, according to figures from the
title: TUTOR PROGRAM OFFERED BY LAW IS GOING UNUSED

body: Among the thousands of stores in New York's low-income neighborhoods, labor unions have virtually no presence, except in a few supermarkets. But in a remarkable culmination to a yearlong struggle, 95 workers at a chain of 10 sneaker stores have formed a union. For much of last year, workers with the sneaker chain, Footco, protested what they said
title: In Modern Rarity, Workers Form Union at Small Chain

body: One man was fatally stabbed and another injured late on Friday during a knife fight among card players in the back of a Brooklyn barbershop, the police and area residents said. One of the men, Osiris Sanchez, 25, who was stabbed in the chest at the Garcia Barbershop at 1245 Halsey Street in Bushwick about 10 p.m., was taken to Wyckoff Heights
title: 2 Men Are Stabbed, One Fatally, In Fight in Brooklyn Barbershop

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used the first State of the City speech of his new term yesterday to call for a drastic change in the World Trade Center development plan so the project can finally move forward. He also asked unions to accept changes to health insurance and pension benefits, whose costs, he said, ''have spiraled out of control.'' In an
title: MAYOR, IN SPEECH, URGES SWIFT PACE AT GROUND ZERO

body: As the pay and purchasing power of Manhattan residents have moved higher and higher, incomes in all four of the boroughs outside Manhattan have trailed inflation over the last few years, in a stark example of the increasing income disparity in New York City. In terms of wages, Manhattan families are doing better on average than those in the rest of
title: Wage Squeeze Hits All of City But Manhattan

body: Look in just about any bodega in the city's poorer neighborhoods and it is easy to find shelves well-stocked with potato chips, sodas and doughnuts. But just try to find something healthier like fruits or vegetables. For many low-income city residents, such bodegas are more common shopping options than supermarkets with a much larger roster of
title: Bodegas Are Asked by Health Officials to Help Push a Better Diet in Poorer Neighborhoods

body: When Christine C. Quinn secured enough support last week to become the next City Council speaker, a subtle shift in the political landscape of the city became evident: The Brooklyn Democratic Party was back, playing a role, albeit a minor one, in her victory. The party provided support that helped clinch Ms. Quinn's victory, potentially giving the
title: Brooklyn Democrats Regain Some Clout After Scandals
